choices.text: FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 < 30%
FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <70%
FEV1/FVC<0.7 and FEV1< 50%
Both A and C

questions.text: The Gold's criteria for very severe COPD is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 < 30%

 

Option A:

 

According to the GOLD (Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease) criteria for staging chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), very severe COPD is classified as Stage IV. This stage is defined by a FEV1/FVC ratio (forced expiratory volume in one second/forced vital capacity) less than 0.7, which indicates the presence of airflow limitation, and a FEV1 less than 30% of the predicted value. This level of FEV1 signifies a very severe reduction in lung function and typically corresponds with significant symptoms and health status impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Note:

 

  • Currently Class C+D have been combined and called Class E
  • Classification of types have been updated.

 

Reference: GOLD 2023 guidelines

choices.text: Consuming large amounts of alcohol

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a history of asthma presents to the clinic with worsening wheezing, cough, and shortness of breath. Which of the following is the LEAST likely trigger for his current exacerbation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Consuming large amounts of alcohol

 

Option D:

 

While excessive alcohol consumption can indirectly worsen asthma symptoms through dehydration or disrupted sleep, it is not a direct trigger for bronchoconstriction and airway inflammation.

 

Triggers for airway narrowing in asthma: 1. Allergens 2. Irritants 3. Viral infections 4. Exercise and cold, dry air 5. Air pollution 6. Drugs 7. Occupational exposures 8. Hormonal changes 9. Pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

Options A. Exposure to cat dander: Animal dander is a common allergen and a well-known trigger for asthma exacerbations.

 

Options B. Recent URI with rhinovirus: Viral respiratory infections are among the most common triggers of asthma exacerbations.

 

Options C. Using a beta-blocker for hypertension: Beta-blockers can worsen asthma symptoms due to their bronchoconstrictive effects by blocking beta-2 receptors in the airways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcohol consumption is not a direct trigger for bronchoconstriction and airway inflammation in asthma.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy with a family history of asthma and allergies presents with recurrent wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath. Genetic testing is being considered to assess his risk of developing persistent asthma. Which of the following genes is MOST consistently associated with asthma susceptibility?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ORMDL3

 

Option C:

 

ORMDL3 is one of the most consistently identified genes associated with asthma susceptibility, particularly in early-onset disease. It is involved in airway remodeling and inflammation.

 

Asssociated genes in asthma: The most consistently identified include ORMDL3/GSDMB (in the 17q21 chromosomal region), ADAM33, DPP-10, TSLP, IL-12, IL-33, ST2, HLA-DQB1, HLA-DQB2, TLR1, and IL6R.

 

Explanation:

 

Options A. CFTR: Associated with cystic fibrosis.

 

Options B. BRCA1: Associated with breast and ovarian cancer.

 

Options D. KCNH2: Associated with long QT syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ORMDL3 is the most  consistently associated gene with asthma susceptibility.

choices.text: Positive skin test for inhaled allergens
A type of extrinsic asthma

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman experiences recurrent episodes of wheezing and nasal congestion after taking aspirin for a headache. Which of the following is most likely associated with her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nasal polyps

 

Option C:

 

The triad of asthma, aspirin sensitivity, and nasal polyps is characteristic of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD) – previously called as Samters triad.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Raised serum IgE levels: Associated with allergic asthma, not AERD.

 

Option B. Positive skin test for inhaled allergens: Also associated with allergic asthma.

 

Option D. A type of extrinsic asthma: AERD is a type of intrinsic (non-allergic) asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasal polyps are characteristic of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD) in patients with asthma and aspirin sensitivity.

choices.text: Demonstration of reversible obstruction on PFT

questions.text: A patient experiences recurrent episodes of wheezing, cough, and shortness of breath. Which test is most reliable in confirming the diagnosis of bronchial asthma?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Demonstration of reversible obstruction on PFT

 

Option D:

 

A significant improvement in FEV1 after bronchodilator administration on PFTs is the most reliable indicator of reversible airflow obstruction, the hallmark of asthma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chest X-ray: Typically normal in asthma.

 

Option B. Skin prick test: Identifies allergic triggers, but not diagnostic of asthma.

 

Option C. FEV1 measurement: May show obstruction, but reversibility is key for diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Demonstration of reversible obstruction on PFTs is the most reliable test for confirming the diagnosis of bronchial asthma.

questions.text: After administering a short-acting beta-agonist (SABA) inhaler like salbutamol for suspected asthma, how long should you wait before repeating spirometry to assess for reversibility?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 15 minutes

 

Option B:

 

The bronchodilator effect of SABAs like salbutamol typically peaks around 15 minutes after administration.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 5 minutes: Too soon; the full effect of the bronchodilator may not yet be evident.

 

Option C. 30 minutes and, D. 60 minutes: Waiting longer may lead to the bronchodilator effect wearing off, giving a false negative result.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wait 15 minutes after administering a SABA inhaler like salbutamol before repeating spirometry to assess for reversibility.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with stable COPD and resting oxygen saturation of 88% on room air is started on long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT). Which of the following is NOT a known benefit of LTOT in COPD?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased hematocrit

 

Explanation:

 

Long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) in COPD patients with chronic hypoxemia (resting SpO2 ≤ 88%) has several established benefits:

 

  • Improved survival: LTOT has been shown to increase survival in patients with severe resting hypoxemia (PaO2 ≤ 55 mmHg).
  • Reduced pulmonary vascular resistance: LTOT helps reduce pulmonary hypertension by improving oxygenation and decreasing hypoxic vasoconstriction.
  • Improved V/Q mismatch: By increasing alveolar oxygen tension, LTOT can help correct the ventilation-perfusion mismatch often seen in COPD.
  • Decreased hematocrit (polycythemia): Chronic hypoxemia can trigger an increase in red blood cell production (polycythemia). LTOT can reverse this effect

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) in COPD improves survival, reduces pulmonary vascular resistance, and improves V/Q mismatch, but it does not increase hematocrit.

choices.text: Resting PaO2 of 54 mmHg and evidence of cor pulmonale
Resting SpO2 of 88% on room air and a history of two COPD exacerbations in the past year
Resting PaO2 of 58 mmHg and a hematocrit of 55%
Resting SpO2 of 89% and a normal 6-minute walk distance

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with severe emphysema secondary to alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is being evaluated for long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT). Which of the following scenarios would NOT meet the criteria for LTOT in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Resting SpO2 of 89% and a normal 6-minute walk distance

 

Option D:

 

The current guidelines for LTOT in COPD recommend it for patients with:

 

  • Resting PaO2 ≤ 55 mmHg OR SaO2 ≤ 88% on room air
  • OR PaO2 56-59 mmHg or SaO2 89% with evidence of:
    • Cor pulmonale
    • Polycythemia (Hct > 55%)
    • Pulmonary hypertension

 

Option D. does not meet these criteria as the patient's oxygen saturation is above 88% and there's no evidence of end-organ damage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Resting PaO2 of 54 mmHg and evidence of cor pulmonale: Meets the criteria for LTOT.

 

Option B. Resting SpO2 of 88% and a history of two COPD exacerbations: Meets the criteria due to low SpO2.

 

Option C. Resting PaO2 of 58 mmHg and a hematocrit of 55%: Meets the criteria due to low PaO2 and high hematocrit

 

Educational Objective:

 

Resting SpO2 of 89% and a normal 6-minute walk distance do not meet the criteria for long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) in COPD.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with severe COPD and chronic bronchitis presents with a history of frequent exacerbations despite optimal bronchodilator therapy. He has a 50-pack-year smoking history and continues to smoke 1 pack per day. Which of the following medications is most likely to reduce the frequency of his exacerbations?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Roflumilast 

 

Option C:

 

Roflumilast is specifically indicated for severe COPD with chronic bronchitis and frequent exacerbations despite optimized bronchodilator therapy. It works by reducing inflammation and mucus production.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tiotropium: While a LAMA improves lung function and symptoms, it doesn't have the same impact on exacerbation frequency as roflumilast.

 

Option B. Salmeterol: LABAs improve lung function but don't specifically target exacerbations like roflumilast.

 

Option D. Prednisolone: Oral steroids are used for acute exacerbations, not long-term prevention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Roflumilast (PDE4 inhibitor) is indicated for severe COPD with chronic bronchitis and frequent exacerbations, reducing inflammation and mucus production.

questions.text: A 60-year-old smoker with a history of COPD presents to the clinic with a COPD Assessment Test (CAT) score of 15 and two hospitalizations for COPD exacerbations in the past year. Which GOLD category does he belong to based on the 2023 GOLD guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) GOLD E

 

Option D:

 

The 2023 GOLD guidelines have replaced categories C and D with category E. Group E patients have a high symptom burden (CAT score ≥10) or history of exacerbations, regardless of airflow limitation severity.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. GOLD A: Low risk, low symptoms

 

Option B. GOLD B: Low risk, high symptoms

 

Option C. GOLD C: No longer used in the 2023 guidelines

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with a high symptom burden (CAT score ≥10) or a history of exacerbations belong to GOLD category E according to the 2023 GOLD guidelines.

choices.text: Increased diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (DLCO)

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a long history of smoking and progressive dyspnea presents with a barrel chest and expiratory wheezing. Which of the following pulmonary function test (PFT) findings is NOT typically seen in emphysema?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (DLCO)

 

Option C:

 

Emphysema destroys alveoli, leading to decreased gas exchange surface area and a reduced DLCO.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increased total lung capacity (TLC): Common in emphysema due to air trapping and hyperinflation.

 

Option B. Decreased FEV1/FVC ratio: Hallmark of obstructive lung disease like emphysema.

 

Option D. Decreased vital capacity (VC): Often seen in emphysema due to severe air trapping - also called as ‘pseudo-restriction’

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased DLCO is not typically seen in emphysema, as this condition reduces gas exchange surface area, leading to decreased DLCO.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with severe COPD undergoes spirometry after bronchodilator administration. His FEV1 is 28% of the predicted value. Which GOLD stage does he belong to?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) GOLD 4 (Very Severe)

 

Option D:

 

Very severe COPD (GOLD 4) is defined by a post-bronchodilator FEV1 less than 30% of the predicted value.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. GOLD 1 (Mild): FEV1 ≥ 80% predicted

 

Option B. GOLD 2 (Moderate): 50% ≤ FEV1 < 80% predicted

 

Option C. GOLD 3 (Severe): 30% ≤ FEV1 < 50% predicted

 

Educational Objective:

 

Very severe COPD (GOLD 4) is defined by a post-bronchodilator FEV1 less than 30% of the predicted value.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with COPD reports that she becomes short of breath when walking at her own pace on level ground, and sometimes has to stop for breath. Based on the modified Medical Research Council (mMRC) dyspnea scale, what is her dyspnea grade?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) mMRC 2

 

Option C:

 

The patient's description matches the mMRC grade 2 criterion: "Short of breath when hurrying on the level or walking up a slight hill."

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. mMRC 0: No breathlessness except with strenuous exercise.

 

Option B. mMRC 1: Breathlessness when hurrying or walking up a slight hill.

 

Option D. mMRC 3: Walks slower than others of same age due to breathlessness or stops for breath at own pace.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patient's description matches the mMRC grade 2 criterion: "Short of breath when hurrying on the level or walking up a slight hill."

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a component of the BODE index, a prognostic tool in COPD that incorporates the mMRC dyspnea scale?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Exacerbation frequency

 

Option D:

 

The BODE index includes BMI, airflow obstruction (FEV1), dyspnea (mMRC grade), and exercise capacity (6-minute walk distance). Exacerbation frequency, while important, is not included in the BODE index.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. BMI: Lower BMI is associated with worse prognosis in COPD.

 

Option B. Airflow obstruction (FEV1): Lower FEV1 indicates worse lung function and prognosis.

 

Option C. Dyspnea (mMRC grade): Higer mMRC grade indicates more severe dyspnea and worse prognosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exacerbation frequency, while important, is not included in the BODE index, which incorporates BMI, FEV1, mMRC dyspnea grade, and 6-minute walk distance.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a 20-pack-year smoking history presents with progressive shortness of breath and chronic cough. Spirometry reveals an FEV1 of 62% predicted and an FEV1/FVC ratio of 39%. After administration of a bronchodilator (BD), the FEV1 improves to 75% predicted, and the FEV1/FVC ratio improves to 73%. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Asthma

 

Option A:

 

Post BD FEV1/FVC > 70% rules out COPD and establishes the diagnosis of asthma. Note that this patient also has a significant improvement in FEV1 post bronchodilator (FEV1 ≥ 12%/200mL)

 

Explanation:  

 

Option B. COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease): Although COPD can also cause airflow obstruction, it is typically less reversible with bronchodilators.

 

Option C. Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA): While ABPA can cause asthma-like symptoms, it is usually associated with elevated IgE levels and positive Aspergillus serology.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis: Primarily seen in smokers and associated with cystic lung lesions on imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-bronchodilator FEV1/FVC > 70% rules out COPD and establishes the diagnosis of asthma, with significant improvement in FEV1 indicating reversibility.

choices.text: Can occur due to protease-antiprotease imbalance

questions.text: A 60-year-old smoker with a long-standing history of dyspnea and a scanty cough experiences relief with bronchodilator therapy. Pulmonary function tests reveal an FEV1/FVC 54% and FEV1 50% predicted. Post Bronchodilator neb his FEV1/FVC improved to 65% and FEV1 improved to 57%. Which of the following is NOT a typical feature of this patient's likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased residual volume (RV)

 

Option B:

 

COPD is characterized by air trapping, which leads to an increased residual volume (RV).

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Irreversible airflow limitation: This is the hallmark of COPD.

 

Option C. Affects small airways: Small airway inflammation and narrowing contribute to COPD.

 

Option D. Can occurs due to protease-antiprotease imbalance: This imbalance contributes to the destruction of lung tissue in emphysema, which is a major cause of COPD

 

Educational Objective:

 

COPD is characterized by air trapping, leading to an increased residual volume (RV), not decreased.

questions.text: A patient with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is found to have emphysema predominantly affecting the lower lobes of the lungs. Which type of emphysema is this most consistent with?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Panacinar emphysema

 

Option C:

 

Panacinar emphysema involves uniform destruction of the acinus (respiratory bronchiole, alveolar ducts, and alveoli) and is typically seen in the lower lobes of patients with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Centrilobular emphysema: Predominantly affects the respiratory bronchioles and is more common in smokers.

 

Option B. Paraseptal emphysema: Occurs adjacent to pleural surfaces and interlobular septa.

 

Option D. Bullous emphysema: Refers to large bullae formation, not a distinct type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Panacinar emphysema involves uniform destruction of the acinus and is typically seen in the lower lobes of patients with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

choices.text: ICS reduce mortality in COPD
ICS reduce the frequency of COPD exacerbations.
ICS reduce the rate of decline of FEV1 in COPD
ICS reduce the incidence of pneumonia in COPD.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with moderate to severe COPD is being considered for treatment with inhaled corticosteroids (ICS). Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the use of ICS in COPD?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ICS reduce the frequency of COPD exacerbations.

 

Option B:

 

While ICS don't reduce mortality or slow FEV1 decline in COPD, they have been shown to reduce the frequency of exacerbations.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. ICS reduce mortality in COPD: Not true. But recently, triple combinations (LABA + LAMA + ICS) in selected patients (Group E) has shown to reduce mortality.

 

Option C. ICS reduce the rate of decline of FEV1 in COPD: Not true.

 

Option D. ICS reduce the incidence of pneumonia in COPD: Actually, ICS may slightly increase the risk of pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) reduce the frequency of COPD exacerbations.

choices.text: Nocturnal BiPAP (bilevel positive airway pressure)

questions.text: A 69-year-old smoker with COPD has had three hospitalizations for exacerbations in the past year. He is already on LABA(long acting beta 2 agonist), LAMA long acting muscarinic antagonist) and ICS (inhaled corticosteroids). Which of the following treatments is most likely to decrease the frequency of his exacerbations?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Daily azithromycin 500mg

 

Option A:

 

This patient has severe COPD with frequent exacerbations despite being on triple therapy(LABA, LAMA, and ICS). In such cases, studies have shown that daily azithromycin 250mg or 500mg can significantly reduce the frequency of exacerbations due to its anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory effects.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option B. Continuous oxygen at 2 L/min: While oxygen therapy is crucial for patients with chronic hypoxemia, it doesn't directly reduce the frequency of exacerbations.

 

Option C. Nocturnal BiPAP (bilevel positive airway pressure): This is indicated for COPD patients with hypercapnic respiratory failure or nocturnal desaturation, not as a primary prevention for exacerbations.

 

Option D. Inhaled corticosteroids: The patient is already on ICS, and further increasing the dose is unlikely to provide additional benefit in preventing exacerbations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Daily azithromycin 500mg can significantly reduce the frequency of exacerbations in severe COPD patients already on LABA, LAMA, and ICS therapy.

choices.text: Hypoxemia (PaO2 < 60 mmHg on room air)

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with an acute exacerbation of COPD presents with respiratory distress, tachypnea, and altered mental status. Which of the following would be an absolute contraindication to initiating non-invasive ventilation (NIV)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inability to protect airway

 

Option D:

 

Impaired consciousness and inability to protect the airway are absolute contraindications to NIV, as they increase the risk of aspiration and respiratory arrest.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Hypoxemia (PaO2 < 60 mmHg on room air): NIV can be used to improve oxygenation in COPD exacerbations.

 

Option B. Hypercapnia (PaCO2 > 50 mmHg): NIV can improve ventilation and reduce CO2 levels.

 

Option C. Respiratory acidosis (pH < 7.35): NIV can help correct acidosis caused by hypercapnia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inability to protect the airway is an absolute contraindication to initiating non-invasive ventilation (NIV) in patients with acute exacerbation of COPD.

questions.text: A 30-year-old occasional smoker presents with a chronic cough and dyspnea on exertion. Physical examination is unremarkable, and chest X-ray is normal. Spirometry reveals an FEV1 of 60% predicted and an FEV1/FVC ratio of 80%. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Preserved Ratio Impaired Spirometry (PRISm)

 

Option C:

 

PRISm is characterized by reduced FEV1 but a normal FEV1/FVC ratio. It's a potential precursor to COPD, particularly in smokers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Asthma: Usually shows a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio with reversibility.

 

Option B. COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease): Requires an FEV1/FVC < 0.70.

 

Option D. Normal lung function: Not possible with reduced FEV1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PRISm (Preserved Ratio Impaired Spirometry) is characterized by a reduced FEV1 with a normal FEV1/FVC ratio, often seen as a potential precursor to COPD.

choices.text: Yes, epinephrine is indicated for all asthma exacerbations.
Yes, but only if she fails to respond to inhaled bronchodilators.
No, epinephrine is only indicated for asthma associated with anaphylaxis or angioedema.
No, epinephrine should only be used in patients with severe asthma exacerbations requiring hospitalization.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of asthma presents with worsening wheezing, cough, and shortness of breath. There is no associated angioedema or urticaria. Her vital signs are stable, and her oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Would intramuscular epinephrine be indicated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) No, epinephrine is only indicated for asthma associated with anaphylaxis or angioedema.

 

Option C:

 

Intramuscular epinephrine is primarily reserved for asthma exacerbations that are accompanied by anaphylaxis or angioedema (severe allergic reactions). In this patient with no signs of anaphylaxis or angioedema, standard asthma treatment with bronchodilators and corticosteroids would be appropriate.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Yes, epinephrine is indicated for all asthma exacerbations: Incorrect. Epinephrine is a potent drug reserved for life-threatening situations like anaphylaxis.

 

Option B. Yes, but only if she fails to respond to inhaled bronchodilators: Incorrect. While epinephrine may be used in refractory cases, it's not the initial therapy for most asthma exacerbations.

 

Option D. No, epinephrine should only be used in patients with severe asthma exacerbations requiring hospitalization: Incorrect. While epinephrine is often used in severe cases, it's indicated for any asthma exacerbation with anaphylaxis or angioedema, regardless of severity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intramuscular epinephrine is only indicated for asthma exacerbations associated with anaphylaxis or angioedema.

choices.text: Low-dose ICS + LABA (long-acting beta-agonist) combination

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with mild persistent asthma is well-controlled on a low-dose inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) as maintenance therapy. She experiences occasional wheezing and shortness of breath, especially after exercise. According to current asthma guidelines, which of the following is the preferred reliever medication for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Low-dose ICS + LABA (long-acting beta-agonist) combination

 

Option D:

 

Current guidelines recommend using a combination inhaler containing both low-dose ICS and a LABA as the preferred reliever medication for ALL patients with asthma, regardless of severity. This approach provides both rapid symptom relief (LABA) and anti-inflammatory effects (ICS), reducing the risk of exacerbations.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Short-acting beta-agonist (SABA) alone: Although SABAs provide quick relief, they don't address underlying inflammation.

 

Option B. Short-acting muscarinic antagonist (SAMA) alone: Less effective than SABAs in most cases.

 

Option C. Low-dose ICS + SABA combination: Not preferred as the LABA component is short-acting and doesn't provide sustained bronchodilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred reliever medication for mild persistent asthma is a combination inhaler containing both low-dose ICS and a LABA.

choices.text: Inhaled short-acting beta-agonists (SABA) as needed
Oral corticosteroids at higher doses

questions.text: A 20-year-old man with severe asthma remains symptomatic despite high-dose inhaled corticosteroids (ICS), long-acting muscarinic antagonists (LAMA), and long-acting beta-agonists (LABA). He is also on oral steroids and montelukast. Further evaluation reveals elevated IgE levels and FeNO (fractional exhaled nitric oxide) of 55 ppb. Which therapy is most likely to be effective for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-IgE therapy (e.g., omalizumab)

 

Option C:

 

Elevated IgE and FeNO suggest atype 2 inflammatory response. Anti-IgE therapy targets this pathway and is indicated in severe allergic asthma not controlled with standard therapy.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Inhaled short-acting beta-agonists (SABA) as needed:  Used for quick relief, not long-term control.

 

Option B. Bronchial thermoplasty: Considered for severe refractory asthma but not the first-line option in this case.

 

Option D. Oral corticosteroids at higher doses: Already on high doses, increasing further may lead to adverse effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-IgE therapy (e.g., omalizumab) is indicated for severe allergic asthma not controlled with standard therapy, especially in the presence of elevated IgE and FeNO levels.

choices.text: Oxygen therapy to maintain SpO2 ≥ 94%
Repeated doses of nebulized salbutamol

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with a history of mild persistent asthma is brought to the ER with an acute exacerbation. His symptoms include wheezing, shortness of breath, and cough. He is using accessory muscles to breathe, and his peak flow is 50% of his personal best. Which of the following is NOT recommended as part of his initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inhaled Formeterol

 

Option D:

 

LABAs (formeterol) are not used in the acute management of asthma exacerbations. They are long-term control medications and have a delayed onset of action.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Oxygen therapy to maintain SpO2 ≥ 94%: Essential to correct hypoxemia.

 

Option B. Repeated doses of nebulized salbutamol: Mainstay of acute bronchodilator therapy.

 

Option C. Oral prednisolone: Oral corticosteroids reduce airway inflammation and are important in exacerbation management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LABAs like formoterol are not used in the acute management of asthma exacerbations due to their delayed onset of action.

questions.text: All of the following are complications of CPAP therapy in OSA except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Difficulty inhaling

 

Option B:

 

Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) can have several common complications, including nasal congestion, claustrophobia, aerophagia, bruised nose and difficulty exhaling. However, difficulty inhaling is not typically associated with CPAP therapy, as the therapy is designed to provide continuous positive pressure to keep the airways open, which should facilitate, rather than impede, inspiration.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Nasal congestion: Common due to the air pressure and can be mitigated with humidification or steroid/saline nasal sprays.

 

Option C. Claustrophobia: A common issue due to the mask, which can make some patients feel confined. Can mitigate by changing mask interface (e.g., nasal prongs)

 

Option D. Aerophagia: Swallowing air, which can lead to bloating and discomfort, is a known side effect of CPAP therapy. Can mitigate to some extent by administering antacids

 

Educational Objective:

 

Difficulty inhaling is not a typical complication of CPAP therapy; common issues include nasal congestion, claustrophobia, and aerophagia.

choices.text: Initiate noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV)
Proceed with endotracheal intubation (ETT) and mechanical ventilation

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of severe COPD presents to the emergency department with an acute exacerbation. He is tachypneic, using accessory muscles of respiration, and his oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. Arterial blood gas analysis shows a pH of 7.28 and PaCO2 of 65 mmHg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Initiate noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV)

 

Option A:

 

This patient is experiencing an acute exacerbation of COPD with significant hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis. NIPPV is the preferred initial management strategy in this scenario, as it can improve ventilation, reduce work of breathing, and potentially avoid the need for invasive mechanical ventilation.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option B. Start IV methylprednisolone: Corticosteroids are indicated in COPD exacerbations, but NIPPV should be prioritized in patients with respiratory failure.

 

Option C. Administer a nebulized bronchodilator: Bronchodilators are important for symptom relief, but they won't address the primary issue of hypercapnia and acidosis.

 

Option D. Proceed with endotracheal intubation (ETT) and mechanical ventilation: While intubation may be necessary if NIPPV fails or the patient deteriorates, it is not the first-line treatment due to its associated risks and complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Initiate noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) for patients with acute COPD exacerbation and respiratory failure to improve ventilation and avoid invasive mechanical ventilation.

questions.text: A young patient with asthma is given a device to monitor his asthma. What is the device?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Peak flow meter

 

Option A:

 

A peak flow meter is a portable device used by asthmatics to measure how fast they can forcefully exhale, providing a quick assessment of airway obstruction.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option B. Spirometer: Measures lung volumes and flow rates during forced exhalation and inhalation.

 

 

Option C. Body plethysmograph: Measures total lung capacity and airway resistance.

 

 

Option D. Incentive spirometer: Helps improve lung function by encouraging deep breaths.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dveice shown in the image is a peak flow meter used by asthmatics to measure how fast they can forcefully exhale, providing a quick assessment of airway obstruction.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with known bronchiectasis is hospitalized with acute worsening of cough, sputum production, and fever. Which antibiotic regimen is most appropriate for this exacerbation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Piperacillin-tazobactam

 

Option C:

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common pathogen in bronchiectasis exacerbations. Piperacillin-tazobactam is a broad-spectrum antibiotic with activity against Pseudomonas and other gram-negative organisms, making it the preferred initial therapy.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Amoxicillin: Not effective against Pseudomonas.

 

Option B. Azithromycin: May be used in chronic management but not first-line for acute exacerbations with Pseudomonas.

 

Option D. Doxycycline: Not effective against Pseudomonas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Piperacillin-tazobactam is the preferred antibiotic for acute exacerbations of bronchiectasis due to its broad-spectrum activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and other gram-negative organisms.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with chronic cough and sputum production undergoes bronchoscopy, which reveals dilated airways and nodular lesions. Bronchial washings culture positive for Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC). Which type of bronchiectasis is most likely associated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Varicose bronchiectasis

 

Option B:

 

 Varicose bronchiectasis, with irregular airway dilation and constriction, is commonly seen in NTM infections like MAC.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Cylindrical bronchiectasis: This type of bronchiectasis is characterized by uniformly dilated airways, typically seen in post-infectious bronchiectasis or bronchiectasis associated with bronchial obstruction.

 

Option C. Cystic bronchiectasis: This is the most severe form of bronchiectasis, with large, balloon-like dilations of the airways. While it can be seen in NTM infections, it's less common than varicose bronchiectasis.

 

Option D. Traction bronchiectasis: This type is caused by fibrosis pulling on the airways, often seen in conditions like tuberculosis or sarcoidosis. It presents with irregular dilations and distortions of the airways but is less common in NTM infections.

 

Key Point: Varicose bronchiectasis is the most common type seen in NTM infections, particularly Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC). The irregular dilations and constrictions of the airways resemble varicose veins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Varicose bronchiectasis, with irregular airway dilation and constriction, is commonly seen in NTM infections like Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC).

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presented after coughing up copious amounts of blood-tinged sputum at his nursing home Physical examination shows digital clubbing and cyanosis of the lips. Coarse crackles are heard throughout the lung fields and his SpO2 is 95%. A chest X-ray reveals increased translucency and tram-track opacities in the right lower lung field. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bronchiectasis

 

Option A:

 

The patient presents with typical symptoms of bronchiectasis, including chronic cough with copious amounts of sputum, hemoptysis, and coarse crackles on auscultation. The presence of tram-track opacities on the chest X-ray is characteristic of bronchiectasis, indicating thickened bronchial walls. Digital clubbing and cyanosis are also associated with chronic hypoxia commonly seen in bronchiectasis.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option B. Chronic bronchitis: Typically seen in patients with a history of smoking and characterized by a chronic, productive cough. However, copious amounts of blood-tinged sputum and signs of chronic hypoxia (e.g., digital clubbing, lip cyanosis) are less typical.

 

Option C. Aspiration pneumonia: Common in patients with a history of stroke, which may result in dysphagia. Patients with aspiration pneumonia may present with dyspnea, cough, and hypoxemia, but would not typically show the tram-track opacities seen in this case.

 

Option D. Emphysema: Usually presents with a history of a chronic cough that is characteristically worse in the mornings, production of small amounts of sputum, and dyspnea. Chest X-rays typically show hyperinflation rather than tram-track opacities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bronchiectasis presents with chronic cough, copious sputum, hemoptysis, coarse crackles, and tram-track opacities on X-ray, along with digital clubbing and cyanosis due to chronic hypoxia.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl presents with productive cough, high fever, poor weight gain, and frequent respiratory infections. Exam reveals crackles in the left lower lung. Chest X-ray shows dilated bronchi and infiltrates. Sputum culture: pink rods on Gram stain, non-lactose fermenting, oxidase positive. She is at increased risk for which condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pancreatitis

 

Option D:

 

The patient's symptoms and findings suggest cystic fibrosis (CF), which is characterized by thick mucus secretions that lead to chronic respiratory infections and bronchiectasis. The bacteria identified, likely Pseudomonas aeruginosa, is common in CF patients. CF also affects the pancreas, leading to an increased risk of pancreatitis.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Cirrhosis:  Although CF can lead to liver disease, pancreatitis is a more immediate and common complication.

 

Option B. Hypothyroidism: Not typically associated with CF.

 

Option C. Panacinar emphysema: More commonly related to alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, not CF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystic fibrosis, characterized by chronic respiratory infections and bronchiectasis, increases the risk of pancreatitis due to thick mucus secretions affecting the pancreas.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man complains of cough, shortness of breath, and daily copious sputum production. He has a history of frequent lung infections. His SpO2 is 95%. Diffuse crackles and wheezing are heard on auscultation throughout the lung fields. A CT scan is shown. The patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hemoptysis

 

Option A:

 

The patient's history and CT findings suggest bronchiectasis, characterized by chronic productive cough and recurrent lung infections. One of the most significant complications of bronchiectasis is hemoptysis due to damage and dilation of the bronchial arteries.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option B. Rhizopus infections: Causes Mucormycosis. Uncommon in bronchiectasis. More common in patients with DKA or COVID19

 

Option C. Pneumothorax: While possible, it is less common in bronchiectasis. More common in Emphysema

 

Option D. Lung cancer: Bronchiectasis is not a risk factor for lung cancer

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bronchiectasis, characterized by chronic productive cough and recurrent lung infections, significantly increases the risk of hemoptysis due to damage and dilation of the bronchial arteries.

choices.text: Cells with multilobular nuclei and enzyme-filled granules
Heavy and light protein chains linked by disulfide bonds
Tubular arrangements of linked heavy chains that slide against one another

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a history of upper respiratory tract infections presents with four other respiratory infections this year and frequent bouts of otitis media. He was diagnosed with bronchiectasis as a child. Which structure is most likely defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tubular arrangements of linked heavy chains that slide against one another

 

Option D:

 

The patient's symptoms suggest primary ciliary dyskinesia (Kartagener syndrome), where the defect is in the cilia's dynein arms. These are tubular arrangements of linked heavy chains that slide against one another to facilitate movement.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Cells with multilobular nuclei and enzyme-filled granules: Refers to neutrophils, not related to this condition.

 

Option B. Collagen α-chains in triplets: Related to collagen structure, not relevant here.

 

Option C. Heavy and light protein chains linked by disulfide bonds: Refers to immunoglobulins, not relevant here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patient's symptoms suggest primary ciliary dyskinesia (Kartagener syndrome), where the defect is in the cilia's dynein arms, which are tubular arrangements of linked heavy chains that slide against one another to facilitate movement.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with cystic fibrosis presents with a persistent cough and frequent respiratory infections over the past year. Sputum cultures have consistently grown a specific pathogen. Given the patient's age and clinical history, which pathogen is most likely responsible for these early respiratory infections?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus aureus

 

Option B:

 

Staphylococcus aureus is the primary pathogen responsible for early respiratory infections in cystic fibrosis patients. It frequently colonizes the respiratory tract of young children with cystic fibrosis and can cause persistent and recurrent infections, leading to inflammation and damage in the lungs.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: This pathogen typically becomes more prevalent in the respiratory tracts of cystic fibrosis patients as they get older and is associated with chronic lung infections and a more rapid decline in lung function.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenzae: This bacterium can cause respiratory infections but is less common and less significant than Staphylococcus aureus in the early stages of cystic fibrosis.

 

Option D. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Although it can cause respiratory infections, it is not the primary pathogen in early cystic fibrosis respiratory infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staphylococcus aureus is the primary pathogen responsible for early respiratory infections in young children with cystic fibrosis, frequently causing persistent and recurrent infections.

choices.text: Increased risk of liver dysfunction post-transplant
Reduced success rates of lung transplantation
Higher likelihood of developing diabetes post-transplant

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient with cystic fibrosis, who has been colonized with Burkholderia cepacia complex (BCC), is scheduled for a lung transplant evaluation. What is a major concern related to BCC colonization in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduced success rates of lung transplantation

 

Option B:

 

Colonization with Burkholderia cepacia complex (BCC) is a significant concern in cystic fibrosis patients undergoing lung transplantation due to the increased risk of post-transplant complications and reduced success rates. BCC is highly resistant to antibiotics and can lead to severe infections.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Increased risk of liver dysfunction post-transplant: This is not specifically related to BCC colonization.

 

Option C. Higher likelihood of developing diabetes post-transplant: Diabetes can occur post-transplant but is not specifically linked to BCC.

 

Option D. Increased risk of gastrointestinal complications: Gastrointestinal issues are common in cystic fibrosis but not specifically related to BCC colonization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkholderia cepacia complex (BCC) colonization in cystic fibrosis patients is a significant concern due to the reduced success rates and increased risk of severe infections post-lung transplantation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of non-CF bronchiectasis presents for a routine follow-up. The patient has experienced a noticeable decline in lung function over the past few years. What is the typical annual decline in FEV1 for patients with non-CF bronchiectasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 50-55 mL per year

 

Option C:

 

Patients with non-CF bronchiectasis typically experience a decline in FEV1 of about 50-55 mL per year, which is significantly higher than the decline observed in healthy individuals (20-30 mL per year). This rapid decline highlights the progressive nature of bronchiectasis and the importance of regular monitoring and management to slow disease progression.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. 10-15 mL per year: This rate is too low and more typical of normal aging in healthy individuals.

 

Option B. 20-30 mL per year: This is the decline seen in healthy controls, not in bronchiectasis patients.

 

Option D. 70-80 mL per year: This rate is higher than what is typically observed in non-CF bronchiectasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with non-CF bronchiectasis typically experience an annual decline in FEV1 of about 50-55 mL, highlighting the progressive nature of the disease.

choices.text: Complete involution of the vas deferens

questions.text: A male patient with cystic fibrosis is found to be infertile despite having normal spermatogenesis. What is the most likely cause of this infertility?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Complete involution of the vas deferens

 

Option B:

 

In cystic fibrosis, nearly 99% of males are infertile due to the complete involution of the vas deferens, despite having normal spermatogenesis.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Obstruction of the epididymis: Not the primary cause.

 

Option C. Defective spermatogenesis: Spermatogenesis is typically normal in CF.

 

Option D. Hormonal imbalances: Infertility in CF is primarily due to anatomical defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cystic fibrosis, nearly 99% of males are infertile due to the complete involution of the vas deferens, despite having normal spermatogenesis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old with cystic fibrosis presents with right lower quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and obstipation. Abdominal X-ray reveals a mass in the ileocecal region with dilated bowel loops. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Distal Intestinal Obstruction Syndrome (DIOS)

 

Option C:

 

Distal Intestinal Obstruction Syndrome (DIOS): This is a common complication in cystic fibrosis patients, caused by the buildup of thick, sticky stools in the distal ileum and cecum. The symptoms described (abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, obstipation) and the radiological finding of a mass in the ileocecal region with dilated bowel loops are classic for DIOS.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Appendicitis: While appendicitis can present with similar symptoms, the presence of a mass in the ileocecal region and the patient's history of cystic fibrosis make DIOS a more likely diagnosis

 

Option B. Crohn's disease: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that can cause abdominal pain and bowel obstruction. However, it is less common in cystic fibrosis patients and typically presents with a different clinical picture and radiological findings

 

Option D. Intussusception: Intussusception is the telescoping of one segment of the intestine into another. While it can cause bowel obstruction, it is more common in children and usually presents with a sausage-shaped mass on palpation, which is not seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Distal Intestinal Obstruction Syndrome (DIOS) is a common complication in cystic fibrosis, characterized by the buildup of thick, sticky stools in the distal ileum and cecum, leading to abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and obstipation.

choices.text: Impaired synthesis of the CFTR protein
Defective chloride channel function at the cell surface
Increased degradation of the CFTR protein in the endoplasmic reticulum
Abnormal post-translational modification of the CFTR protein

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient with cystic fibrosis is found to have the most common mutation seen in these patients. What is the primary defect caused by this mutation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased degradation of the CFTR protein in the endoplasmic reticulum

 

Option C:

 

The most common mutation in cystic fibrosis is delta F508 mutation  and this results in the misfolding of the CFTR protein, leading to its increased degradation in the endoplasmic reticulum. As a result, the defective CFTR protein fails to reach the cell surface, causing impaired chloride and water transport, which characterizes cystic fibrosis.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Impaired synthesis of the CFTR protein: The delta F508 mutation affects protein folding, not synthesis.

 

Option B. Defective chloride channel function at the cell surface: This is a consequence, but the primary issue is the degradation before reaching the cell surface.

 

Option D. Abnormal post-translational modification of the CFTR protein: This is not the main issue with the delta F508 mutation

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common mutation in cystic fibrosis, delta F508, leads to increased degradation of the CFTR protein in the endoplasmic reticulum, preventing it from reaching the cell surface and causing impaired chloride and water transport.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient with cystic fibrosis has a homozygous F508del mutation in the CFTR gene. What is the most appropriate treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Elexacaftor/Tezacaftor/Ivacaftor combination 

 

Option D:

 

The Elexacaftor/Tezacaftor/Ivacaftor combination, known as Trikafta, is the most advanced and effective treatment for patients with the F508del mutation in the CFTR gene. This triple therapy works by correcting the folding defect (Elexacaftor and Tezacaftor) and enhancing the function of the CFTR protein at the cell surface (Ivacaftor), leading to significant improvements in lung function and other clinical outcomes.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Ivacaftor monotherapy: Effective for certain gating mutations but not sufficient for the F508del mutation.

 

Option B. Lumacaftor/Ivacaftor combination: Provides benefit for F508del mutation but is less effective than the triple therapy.

 

Option C. Tezacaftor/Ivacaftor combination: An improvement over Lumacaftor/Ivacaftor but still not as effective as the triple therapy for the F508del mutation

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Elexacaftor/Tezacaftor/Ivacaftor combination (Trikafta) is the most advanced and effective treatment for patients with the F508del mutation in the CFTR gene.

choices.text: Class I mutation leading to no CFTR protein production
Class II mutation causing defective protein processing
Class III mutation resulting in defective channel regulation
Class IV mutation causing decreased conductance

questions.text: A 22-year-old cystic fibrosis patient is found to have a CFTR mutation that results in defective protein processing and impaired channel function. Which type of CFTR defect is most effectively treated with a combination of potentiators and correctors?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Class II mutation causing defective protein processing

 

Option B:

 

Class II CFTR mutations, such as the F508del mutation, result in defective protein processing that leads to misfolded CFTR proteins that are degraded before reaching the cell surface. This type of defect benefits from a combination of correctors and potentiators. Correctors, such as Lumacaftor or Tezacaftor, improve the folding and trafficking of the CFTR protein to the cell surface, while potentiators, such as Ivacaftor, enhance the function of the CFTR protein at the cell surface.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Class I mutation leading to no CFTR protein production: These mutations produce little to no CFTR protein, making correctors and potentiators ineffective.

 

Option C. Class III mutation resulting in defective channel regulation: Typically treated effectively with potentiators alone, as the CFTR protein is present but dysfunctional.

 

Option D. Class IV mutation causing decreased conductance: Potentiators may help, but the primary defect involves reduced channel function rather than misprocessing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Class II CFTR mutations causing defective protein processing are most effectively treated with a combination of correctors and potentiators.

choices.text: Selective intubation of the bleeding lung to remove blood clots
Position the patient with the bleeding side down

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with massive hemoptysis and is desaturating. Which of the following is incorrect according to AAFP guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Selective intubation of the bleeding lung to remove blood clots

 

Option B :

 

According to AAFP guidelines, selective intubation should be performed on the nonbleeding lung, not the bleeding lung. This helps protect the nonbleeding lung from contamination and allows effective ventilation. Avoiding endotracheal intubation is recommended unless truly necessary, and positioning the patient with the bleeding side down helps keep blood out of the nonbleeding lung.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Avoid Endotracheal intubation: Recommended unless absolutely necessary, to use the cough reflex for blood removal.

 

Option C. Insert a single-lumen endotracheal tube: Incorrect as it does not allow for selective ventilation and protection of the nonbleeding lung.

 

Option D. Position the patient with the bleeding side down: Correct as it uses gravitational advantage to prevent blood from entering the nonbleeding lung.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to AAFP guidelines, selective intubation should be performed on the nonbleeding lung, not the bleeding lung, to protect the nonbleeding lung from contamination and ensure effective ventilation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presents with non-massive hemoptysis. What is the most common cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Viral bronchitis

 

Option B:

 

Viral bronchitis is the most common cause of non-massive hemoptysis, typically resulting from inflammation and irritation of the airways. It often presents with a productive cough and blood-tinged sputum, especially in the context of a recent or ongoing respiratory infection.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Tuberculosis: It is one of the most common causes in developing countries like India.

 

Option C. Lung cancer: A significant cause but not the most common.

 

Option D. Pulmonary embolism: Can cause hemoptysis, but it is not the most common cause of non-massive hemoptysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viral bronchitis is the most common cause of non-massive hemoptysis, typically resulting from inflammation and irritation of the airways.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with massive hemoptysis. What is the procedure of choice for controlling the bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bronchial artery embolization

 

Option B:

 

Bronchial artery embolization is the procedure of choice for controlling bleeding in life-threatening cases of hemoptysis as most massive bleeds originate from the bronchial circulation. This interventional radiology technique effectively targets and stops the source of bleeding, providing rapid control and stabilization.

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A. Bronchoscopy: Useful for diagnosis and initial management but not primarily for controlling severe bleeding.

 

Option C. Surgical resection: Considered when embolization fails or is not feasible, but it is more invasive.

 

Option D. Intravenous antibiotic therapy: Used to treat underlying infections but not effective for immediate control of severe bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bronchial artery embolization is the procedure of choice for controlling bleeding in life-threatening cases of massive hemoptysis.

questions.text: All of the following are complications of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary fibrosis

 

OPtion C:

 

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is associated with several complications, including hypertension, stroke, and cardiovascular disease, due to repeated episodes of hypoxia and increased sympathetic activity. Pulmonary fibrosis, however, is not a typical complication of OSA and is more commonly associated with other conditions such as chronic exposure to lung irritants or autoimmune diseases.

 

Explanation:  

 

Options A. Hypertension: Common in OSA due to repeated hypoxic episodes and increased sympathetic activity.

 

Option B. Stroke: Increased risk due to the association of OSA with hypertension and other cardiovascular risk factors.

 

Option D. Cardiovascular disease: Strongly linked with OSA, including conditions such as heart failure and arrhythmias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulmonary fibrosis is not a typical complication of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA); common complications include hypertension, stroke, and cardiovascular disease.
